title: Can we get an updated map of the world?
body: The title says it all. I have been putting together a campaign setting for DND 5e and it would really help if I can get an updated map of the world because  a lot of what the old map showed has changed. :)

There are several reasons why we might not see a full map for a long while - or maybe even ever.  It can make the world feel small (and too modern if everywhere is 'explored'), it can limit options for dramatically new additions (like a new continent or four - see Warcraft's ever-expanding world map), it implies that the majority of characters have access to that information too - and lessens the impact of well traveled characters like Gangplank, Ryze, or Taliyah.

You could argue (and several have) that all of those are manageable issues, or perception problems rather than unfixable issues, but even so they're just a couple more grains on the side of the scale _against_ throwing lots of resources into a player facing world map just now.

Smaller, more personalized maps, are an easier route - they don't suffer many of the issues listed, as well as helping  to deepen our understanding of the character or society that created the map.  The scales more easily tip in our favor :)

We already know way more about the world than anyone else does by virtue of knowing that Bard, Asol, Kindred, and Tahm all actually exist. I don't see why a map is the real problem here.

The issue with in-universe information being relayed to us by in-universe people is that it has very obvious bias. This is a really bad thing for fiction; how are we supposed to hold an informed opinion on a fictional subject if all we get is designed to make one side look better?

> [{quoted}](name=Hellioning,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=z6MVsLE1,comment-id=0001000200000001,timestamp=2017-02-06T20:26:50.174+0000)
>
> We already know way more about the world than anyone else does by virtue of knowing that Bard, Asol, Kindred, and Tahm all actually exist. I don't see why a map is the real problem here.
> 
> The issue with in-universe information being relayed to us by in-universe people is that it has very obvious bias. This is a really bad thing for fiction; how are we supposed to hold an informed opinion on a fictional subject if all we get is designed to make one side look better?

I _could_ argue that every piece of information (except perhaps mathematics) contains bias - even if that bias is often unintentional, innocent, or harmless.  You've seen that even Google Maps has [different country borders](https://qz.com/224821/see-how-borders-change-on-google-maps-depending-on-where-you-view-them/) depending on where in the world you access it from?  Because even the edge of a border, or the ownership of an island, is fraught with political meaning and bias.

However, I concede that it's a weak argument.  A photograph of the planet, unmodified and raw, is very hard to find the bias in - and we could indeed release something like that - but it would fall prey to the other issues of restricting our future options, making the world feel small (blue marble like) etc.

Personally - and you're _very_ free to disagree with me here - I find the biases to be highly informative.  That Jago didn't bother to label some of the ports doesn't help us acquire perfect knowledge of the geography of the planet - but it does tell us how important those places are to him and his business.  That the Shuriman tablet doesn't conform to a linear scale is a pain in the ass for people who want to know its square kilometer area in comparison to Noxus, but suggests that they thought in more relativistic terms than absolute - which could be insight to their thought processes.

You'd not get either of those things from a satellite photograph, instead getting cold hard facts.  To be clear - I totally get it if this pisses you off.  They're both valid directions and at the moment, we're going with the cultural bias one.

As for your last question - 

> how are we supposed to hold an informed opinion on a fictional subject if all we get is designed to make one side look better?

The same way any historian does - by reading between the lines, by applying what you know of the culture and biases, and by finding multiple (equally biased) sources to compare and dig the truth out of.

I like the biases too.  I can glean a lot more from those maps.
I especially appreciate when a place is named after an item found there or something like the "gold and ~~sun~~ sing stone" in the Medarda Heirloom map.
Plus biased maps tend to have more pictographs, which are always fun to interpret.

The Medarda Heirloom was great for that because the inherent bias of Jago gave potential insight in to the culture and structure of the various areas he was doing trade with. Kumangra comes to mind and how he's went through five or so contacts in that time.

> but it would fall prey to the other issues of restricting our future options, making the world feel small (blue marble like) etc.

https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/9/97/The_Earth_seen_from_Apollo_17.jpg

I look at that and feel nothing but awe for the world we live in. imho it makes the world feel more personal and really emphasizes that we own it. It may be a minuscule speck in the universe but seeing it fully and wholly doesn't make it feel small but raises its importance greatly.

> However, I concede that it's a weak argument. A photograph of the planet, unmodified and raw, is very hard to find the bias in - and we could indeed release something like that - but it would fall prey to the other issues of restricting our future options, **making the world feel small (blue marble like) etc.**

What if we see "sketches" of a map by an event or a new champion or champion rework. 

Like if Gangplank (example) would be reworked, then we could see a bigger map (not the whole world map) with more regions and how they are connected to each other. But because of it being only a sketch which Gangplank draw or plundered it from someone at some point, we don´t know if everything on it is true and if there aren´t regions which they didn´t explore yet.

 For Gangplank I could think of that he has a map which is more accurate at coast regions near Bilgewater and gets less accurate the more it goes away from it. To a point where it´s unfinished and doesn´t have regions like Demacia or Noxus in it, but more of Isles like the Shadow Islands or Ionia.

It would give us as players more insight but doesn´t tell us to much. And if there would be a chance in the future it would be good to see it. (Maybe the Piltover/Zaun map tried to accomplish this goal, but for me it was to much zoomed in or confusing, because me trying to compare the old map with this map).

>A photograph of the planet, unmodified and raw, is very hard to find the bias in - and we could indeed release something like that - but it would fall prey to the other issues of restricting our future options, making the world feel small (blue marble like) etc.

Riot hasn't exactly had any problems with changing things because it restricted their future options, and I feel that the current state of lore has made the world feel very small. I don't see how either of these would preclude releasing a 'bird's eye view' map. 

>Personally - and you're very free to disagree with me here - I find the biases to be highly informative. That Jago didn't bother to label some of the ports doesn't help us acquire perfect knowledge of the geography of the planet - but it does tell us how important those places are to him and his business. That the Shuriman tablet doesn't conform to a linear scale is a pain in the ass for people who want to know its square kilometer area in comparison to Noxus, but suggests that they thought in more relativistic terms than absolute - which could be insight to their thought processes.

And if I cared about what Jago thought, or about what a dead and/or dying race's thought processes are, that'd be comforting. (Plus, the second one could just be a shitty mapmaker.) We don't know if Jago is typical of his nation or business in terms of biases, so all we know from the first map is 'this is what this one particular person cares about'.

>The same way any historian does - by reading between the lines, by applying what you know of the culture and biases, and by finding multiple (equally biased) sources to compare and dig the truth out of.

And if we had multiple, equally biased sources, or if we knew a lot about every culture, that'd probably make me feel better.

Yes, I understand that we're still in the early stages of new lore. Those future equally biased sources and cultural information will probably come in time. But we don't have them now. And I'm really tired of waiting for lore.
